INTRODUCCIÓN El área de investigación del diseño de mecanismos óptimos se enfoca en diseñar un mecanismo para producir el resultado más deseable para la entidad que lo opera. Este problema está bien estudiado para el problema de diseño de subastas, donde el mecanismo óptimo es aquel que le brinda al vendedor la mayor ganancia. Aquí, el enfoque clásico es diseñar un mecanismo dado la distribución previa de la cual se extraen las preferencias de los postores (Ver, por ejemplo, [12, 4]). Recientemente, Goldberg et al. [9] introdujeron el uso del análisis competitivo del peor caso (ver, por ejemplo, [3]) para analizar el rendimiento de subastas que no tienen conocimiento de la distribución previa. El objetivo de este trabajo es diseñar una subasta que logre una fracción constante grande de la ganancia alcanzable por un mecanismo óptimo que conoce la distribución previa de antemano. Los resultados positivos en esta dirección son impulsados por la observación de que en subastas de un número de unidades idénticas, gran parte de la distribución de la cual se extraen los postores puede ser deducida sobre la marcha por la subasta mientras se lleva a cabo [9, 14, 2]. El rendimiento de una subasta en un análisis competitivo de peor caso se mide por su relación competitiva, la proporción entre un rendimiento de referencia y el rendimiento de la subasta en la distribución de entrada que maximiza esta proporción. El Santo Grial del análisis competitivo del peor caso de subastas es la subasta que logra la proporción competitiva óptima (tan pequeña como sea posible). Desde [9], esta búsqueda ha llevado a una mejor comprensión de la naturaleza de la subasta óptima, las técnicas para la fijación de precios sobre la marcha en estos escenarios y la proporción competitiva de la subasta óptima [5, 7, 8]. En este artículo continuamos esta línea de investigación mejorando en todas estas direcciones. Además, presentamos evidencia que corrobora la conjetura de que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo de las subastas. Este resultado valida aún más el uso del análisis competitivo para medir el rendimiento de una subasta. Consideramos el problema de la subasta de un solo artículo, multiunidad y demanda unitaria. En una subasta de este tipo, hay muchas unidades de un solo artículo disponibles para la venta a postores que desean solo una unidad. Cada postor tiene una valoración que representa cuánto vale el artículo para él. La subasta se realiza solicitando una oferta sellada de cada uno de los postores y decidiendo la asignación de unidades a los postores y los precios a ser pagados por los postores. Se asume que los postores realizan sus ofertas con el fin de maximizar su utilidad personal, la diferencia entre su valoración y el precio que pagan. Para abordar el problema de diseñar y analizar subastas donde los postores pueden declarar falsamente sus valoraciones para obtener un mejor trato, adoptaremos el concepto de diseño de mecanismos veraces (ver, por ejemplo, [9, 15, 13]). En una subasta veraz, revelar la verdadera valoración como oferta es una estrategia óptima para cada postor, independientemente de las ofertas de los demás postores. En este documento, restringiremos nuestra atención a las subastas veraces (también conocidas como compatibles con incentivos o a prueba de estrategias). Un caso especial particularmente interesante del problema de la subasta es el caso de
suministro ilimitado
. En este caso, el número de unidades en venta es al menos igual al número de postores en la subasta. Esto es natural para la venta de bienes digitales donde hay un costo insignificante para duplicar y distribuir el bien. La televisión de pago por visión y los archivos de audio descargables son ejemplos de tales bienes. El marco competitivo introducido en [9] y posteriormente refinado en [5] utiliza la ganancia del mecanismo de precios único óptimo omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades como referencia para el análisis competitivo. La suposición de que se venden dos o más unidades es necesaria porque en el peor de los casos es imposible obtener una fracción constante de la ganancia del mecanismo óptimo cuando vende solo una unidad [9]. En este marco de análisis competitivo, se dice que una subasta es β-competitiva si logra un beneficio que está dentro de un factor de β ≥ 1 del beneficio de referencia en cada entrada. La subasta óptima es aquella que es β-competitiva con el valor mínimo de β. Antes de este trabajo, la subasta más conocida para el caso de
suministro ilimitado
tenía una proporción competitiva de 3.39 [7] y el mejor límite inferior conocido era de 2.42 [8]. Para el caso de suministro limitado, las subastas pueden lograr ratios competitivos considerablemente mejores. Cuando solo hay dos unidades en venta, la subasta óptima proporciona una proporción competitiva de 2, que coincide con el límite inferior para dos unidades. Cuando hay tres unidades en venta, la mejor subasta previamente conocida tuvo una relación competitiva de 2.3, en comparación con un límite inferior de 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8]. Los resultados de este documento son los siguientes: • Presentamos la subasta de tres unidades que es óptimamente competitiva frente a las ganancias del mecanismo de precio único omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades. Esta subasta logra una proporción competitiva de 13/6, igualando el límite inferior de [8] (Sección 3). • Mostramos que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo. Al hacerlo, proporcionamos una subasta óptima de tres postores para referencias generalizadas (Sección 4). • Presentamos una técnica general para convertir una subasta de oferta limitada en una subasta de
oferta ilimitada
, donde es posible utilizar la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta limitada para obtener un límite en la proporción competitiva de la subasta de
oferta ilimitada
.

Hartline Microsoft Research 1065 La Avenida) Mountain View, CA 94043 hartline@microsoft.com Robert McGrew ∗ Computer Science Department Stanford University Stanford, CA 94305 bmcgrew@stanford.edu ABSTRACT We investigate the class of single-round, sealed-bid auctions for a set of identical items to bidders who each desire one unit.
We adopt the worst-case competitive framework defined by [9, 5] that compares the profit of an auction to that of an optimal single-price sale of least two items.
In this paper, we first derive an optimal auction for three items, answering an open question from [8].
Second, we show that the form of this auction is independent of the competitive framework used.
Third, we propose a schema for converting a given limited-supply auction into an unlimited supply auction.

Applying this technique to our optimal auction for three items, we achieve an auction with a competitive ratio of 3.25, which improves upon the previously best-known competitive ratio of 3.39 from [7].

Finally, we generalize a result from [8] and extend our understanding of the nature of the optimal competitive auction by showing that the optimal competitive auction occasionally offers prices that are higher than all bid values.

Categories and Subject Descriptors F.2.2 [Analysis of Algorithms and Problem Complexity]: Nonnumerical Algorithms and Problems; J.4 [Social and Behavioral Sciences]: Economics General Terms Algorithms, Economics, Theory 1.
INTRODUCTION The research area of optimal mechanism design looks at designing a mechanism to produce the most desirable outcome for the entity running the mechanism.
This problem is well studied for the auction design problem where the optimal mechanism is the one that brings the seller the most profit.
Here, the classical approach is to design such a mechanism given the prior distribution from which the bidders preferences are drawn (See e.g., [12, 4]).
Recently Goldberg et al. [9] introduced the use of worst-case competitive analysis (See e.g., [3]) to analyze the performance of auctions that have no knowledge of the prior distribution.
The goal of such work is to design an auction that achieves a large constant fraction of the profit attainable by an optimal mechanism that knows the prior distribution in advance.

Positive results in this direction are fueled by the observation that in auctions for a number of identical units, much of the distribution from which the bidders are drawn can be deduced on the fly by the auction as it is being run [9, 14, 2].

The performance of an auction in such a worst-case competitive analysis is measured by its competitive ratio, the ratio between a benchmark performance and the auctions performance on the input distribution that maximizes this ratio.
The holy grail of the worstcase competitive analysis of auctions is the auction that achieves the optimal competitive ratio (as small as possible).

Since [9] this search has led to improved understanding of the nature of the optimal auction, the techniques for on-the-fly pricing in these scenarios, and the competitive ratio of the optimal auction [5, 7, 8].
In this paper we continue this line of research by improving in all of these directions.
Furthermore, we give evidence corroborating the conjecture that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in the auctions competitive analysis.
This result further validates the use of competitive analysis in gauging auction performance.
We consider the single item, multi-unit, unit-demand auction problem.
In such an auction there are many units of a single item available for sale to bidders who each desire only one unit.
Each bidder has a valuation representing how much the item is worth to him.
The auction is performed by soliciting a sealed bid from each of the bidders and deciding on the allocation of units to bidders and the prices to be paid by the bidders.
The bidders are assumed to bid so as to maximize their personal utility, the difference between their valuation and the price they pay.

To handle the problem of designing and analyzing auctions where bidders may falsely declare their valuations to get a better deal, we will adopt the solution concept of truthful mechanism design (see, e.g., [9, 15, 13]).
In a truthful auction, revealing ones true valuation as ones bid is an optimal strategy for each bidder regardless of the bids of the other bidders.
In this paper, we will restrict our attention to truthful (a.k.a., incentive compatible or strategyproof) auctions.
A particularly interesting special case of the auction problem is the unlimited supply case.
In this case the number of units for sale is at least the number of bidders in the auction.
This is natural for the sale of digital goods where there is negligible cost for duplicating 175 and distributing the good.
Pay-per-view television and downloadable audio files are examples of such goods.

The competitive framework introduced in [9] and further refined in [5] uses the profit of the optimal omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units as the benchmark for competitive analysis.

The assumption that two or more units are sold is necessary because in the worst case it is impossible to obtain a constant fraction of the profit of the optimal mechanism when it sells only one unit [9].
In this framework for competitive analysis, an auction is said to be β-competitive if it achieves a profit that is within a factor of β ≥ 1 of the benchmark profit on every input.
The optimal auction is the one which is β-competitive with the minimum value of β.
Previous to this work, the best known auction for the unlimited supply case had a competitive ratio of 3.39 [7] and the best lower bound known was 2.42 [8].
For the limited supply case, auctions can achieve substantially better competitive ratios.
When there are only two units for sale, the optimal auction gives a competitive ratio of 2, which matches the lower bound for two units.
When there are three units for sale, the best previously known auction had a competitive ratio of 2.3, compared with a lower bound of 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8].

The results of this paper are as follows: • We give the auction for three units that is optimally competitive against the profit of the omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units.

This auction achieves a competitive ratio of 13/6, matching the lower bound from [8] (Section 3). • We show that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in competitive analysis.

In doing so, we give an optimal three bidder auction for generalized benchmarks (Section 4). • We give a general technique for converting a limited supply auction into an unlimited supply auction where it is possible to use the competitive ratio of the limited supply auction to obtain a bound on the competitive ratio of the unlimited supply auction.

We refer to auctions derived from this framework as aggregation auctions (Section 5). • We improve on the best known competitive ratio by proving that the
aggregation auction
constructed from our optimal three-unit auction is 3.25-competitive (Section 5.1). • Assuming that the conjecture that the optimal -unit auction has a competitive ratio that matches the lower bound proved in [8], we show that this optimal auction for ≥ 3 on some inputs will occasionally offer prices that are higher than any bid in that input (Section 6).
For the three-unit case where we have shown that the lower bound of [8] is tight, this observation led to our construction of the optimal three-unit auction. 2.

This mechanism is a special case of a general cost-sharing schema due to Moulin and Shenker [11].
The goal of profit extraction is, given bids b, to extract a target value R of profit from some subset of the bidders.

CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK We have found the optimal auction for the three-unit limitedsupply case, and shown that its structure is essentially independent of the benchmark used in its competitive analysis.
We have then used this auction to derive the best known auction for the unlimited supply case.
Our work leaves many interesting open questions.
We found that the lower bound of [8] is matched by an auction for three bidders, 181 even when competing against generalized benchmarks.
The most interesting open question from our work is whether the lower bound from Theorem 2 can be matched by an auction for more than three bidders.
We conjecture that it can.
Second, we consider whether our techniques can be extended to find optimal auctions for greater numbers of bidders.

The use of our analytic solution method requires knowledge of a restricted class of auctions which is large enough to contain an optimal auction but small enough that the optimal auction in this class can be found explicitly through analytic methods.
No class of auctions which meets these criteria is known even for the four bidder case.
Also, when the number of bidders is greater than three, it might be the case that the optimal auction is not expressible in terms of elementary functions.
Another interesting set of open questions concerns aggregation auctions.

As we show, the
aggregation auction
for Υ3 outperforms the
aggregation auction
for Υ2 and it appears that the aggregation auction for Υ3 is better than Υm for m > 3.
We leave verification of this conjecture for future work.

We also show that Υ3 is not the best three-bidder auction for use in an
aggregation auction
, but the auction that beats it is able to reduce the competitive ratio of the overall auction only a little bit.

It would be interesting to know whether for any m there is an m-
aggregation auction
that substantially improves on the competitive ratio of AggΥm .
Finally, we remark that very little is known about the structure of the optimal competitive auction.
In our auction Υ3, the sales price for a given bidder is restricted either to be one of the other bid values or to be higher than all other bid values.
The optimal auction for two bidders, the 1-unit Vickrey auction, also falls within this class of auctions, as its sales prices are restricted to bid values.
We conjecture that an optimal auction for any number of bidders lies within this class.

Our paper provides partial evidence for this conjecture: the lower bound of Section 6 on conservative auctions shows that the optimal auction must offer sales prices higher than any bid value if the lower bound of Theorem 2 is tight, as is conjectured.
It remains to show that optimal auctions otherwise only offer sales prices at bid values. 8.

INTRODUCCIÓN El área de investigación del diseño de mecanismos óptimos se enfoca en diseñar un mecanismo para producir el resultado más deseable para la entidad que lo opera. Este problema está bien estudiado para el problema de diseño de subastas, donde el mecanismo óptimo es aquel que le brinda al vendedor la mayor ganancia. Aquí, el enfoque clásico es diseñar un mecanismo dado la distribución previa de la cual se extraen las preferencias de los postores (Ver, por ejemplo, [12, 4]). Recientemente, Goldberg et al. [9] introdujeron el uso del análisis competitivo del peor caso (ver, por ejemplo, [3]) para analizar el rendimiento de subastas que no tienen conocimiento de la distribución previa. El objetivo de este trabajo es diseñar una subasta que logre una fracción constante grande de la ganancia alcanzable por un mecanismo óptimo que conoce la distribución previa de antemano. Los resultados positivos en esta dirección son impulsados por la observación de que en subastas de un número de unidades idénticas, gran parte de la distribución de la cual se extraen los postores puede ser deducida sobre la marcha por la subasta mientras se lleva a cabo [9, 14, 2]. El rendimiento de una subasta en un análisis competitivo de peor caso se mide por su relación competitiva, la proporción entre un rendimiento de referencia y el rendimiento de la subasta en la distribución de entrada que maximiza esta proporción. El Santo Grial del análisis competitivo del peor caso de subastas es la subasta que logra la proporción competitiva óptima (tan pequeña como sea posible). Desde [9], esta búsqueda ha llevado a una mejor comprensión de la naturaleza de la subasta óptima, las técnicas para la fijación de precios sobre la marcha en estos escenarios y la proporción competitiva de la subasta óptima [5, 7, 8]. En este artículo continuamos esta línea de investigación mejorando en todas estas direcciones. Además, presentamos evidencia que corrobora la conjetura de que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo de las subastas. Este resultado valida aún más el uso del análisis competitivo para medir el rendimiento de una subasta. Consideramos el problema de la subasta de un solo artículo, multiunidad y demanda unitaria. En una subasta de este tipo, hay muchas unidades de un solo artículo disponibles para la venta a postores que desean solo una unidad. Cada postor tiene una valoración que representa cuánto vale el artículo para él. La subasta se realiza solicitando una oferta sellada de cada uno de los postores y decidiendo la asignación de unidades a los postores y los precios a ser pagados por los postores. Se asume que los postores realizan sus ofertas con el fin de maximizar su utilidad personal, la diferencia entre su valoración y el precio que pagan. Para abordar el problema de diseñar y analizar subastas donde los postores pueden declarar falsamente sus valoraciones para obtener un mejor trato, adoptaremos el concepto de diseño de mecanismos veraces (ver, por ejemplo, [9, 15, 13]). En una subasta veraz, revelar la verdadera valoración como oferta es una estrategia óptima para cada postor, independientemente de las ofertas de los demás postores. En este documento, restringiremos nuestra atención a las subastas veraces (también conocidas como compatibles con incentivos o a prueba de estrategias). Un caso especial particularmente interesante del problema de la subasta es el caso de suministro ilimitado. En este caso, el número de unidades en venta es al menos igual al número de postores en la subasta. Esto es natural para la venta de bienes digitales donde hay un costo insignificante para duplicar y distribuir el bien. La televisión de pago por visión y los archivos de audio descargables son ejemplos de tales bienes. El marco competitivo introducido en [9] y posteriormente refinado en [5] utiliza la ganancia del mecanismo de precios único óptimo omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades como referencia para el análisis competitivo. La suposición de que se venden dos o más unidades es necesaria porque en el peor de los casos es imposible obtener una fracción constante de la ganancia del mecanismo óptimo cuando vende solo una unidad [9]. En este marco de análisis competitivo, se dice que una subasta es β-competitiva si logra un beneficio que está dentro de un factor de β ≥ 1 del beneficio de referencia en cada entrada. La subasta óptima es aquella que es β-competitiva con el valor mínimo de β. Antes de este trabajo, la subasta más conocida para el caso de suministro ilimitado tenía una proporción competitiva de 3.39 [7] y el mejor límite inferior conocido era de 2.42 [8]. Para el caso de suministro limitado, las subastas pueden lograr ratios competitivos considerablemente mejores. Cuando solo hay dos unidades en venta, la subasta óptima proporciona una proporción competitiva de 2, que coincide con el límite inferior para dos unidades. Cuando hay tres unidades en venta, la mejor subasta previamente conocida tuvo una relación competitiva de 2.3, en comparación con un límite inferior de 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8]. Los resultados de este documento son los siguientes: • Presentamos la subasta de tres unidades que es óptimamente competitiva frente a las ganancias del mecanismo de precio único omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades. Esta subasta logra una proporción competitiva de 13/6, igualando el límite inferior de [8] (Sección 3). • Mostramos que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo. Al hacerlo, proporcionamos una subasta óptima de tres postores para referencias generalizadas (Sección 4). • Presentamos una técnica general para convertir una subasta de oferta limitada en una subasta de oferta ilimitada, donde es posible utilizar la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta limitada para obtener un límite en la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta ilimitada. Nos referimos a las subastas derivadas de este marco como subastas de agregación (Sección 5). • Mejoramos la mejor proporción competitiva conocida al demostrar que la
subasta de agregación
construida a partir de nuestra subasta óptima de tres unidades es 3.25-competitiva (Sección 5.1). • Suponiendo que la conjetura de que la subasta óptima de -unidades tiene una proporción competitiva que coincide con el límite inferior demostrado en [8], mostramos que esta subasta óptima para ≥ 3 en algunos insumos ocasionalmente ofrecerá precios más altos que cualquier oferta en ese insumo (Sección 6). Para el caso de tres unidades en el que hemos demostrado que el límite inferior de [8] es ajustado, esta observación condujo a nuestra construcción de la subasta óptima de tres unidades. 2. Hartline Microsoft Research 1065 La Avenida) Mountain View, CA 94043 hartline@microsoft.com Robert McGrew ∗ Computer Science Department Stanford University Stanford, CA 94305 bmcgrew@stanford.edu ABSTRACT We investigate the class of single-round, sealed-bid auctions for a set of identical items to bidders who each desire one unit.
We adopt the worst-case competitive framework defined by [9, 5] that compares the profit of an auction to that of an optimal single-price sale of least two items.
In this paper, we first derive an optimal auction for three items, answering an open question from [8].
Second, we show that the form of this auction is independent of the competitive framework used.
Third, we propose a schema for converting a given limited-supply auction into an unlimited supply auction.

Applying this technique to our optimal auction for three items, we achieve an auction with a competitive ratio of 3.25, which improves upon the previously best-known competitive ratio of 3.39 from [7].

Finally, we generalize a result from [8] and extend our understanding of the nature of the optimal competitive auction by showing that the optimal competitive auction occasionally offers prices that are higher than all bid values.

INTRODUCTION The research area of optimal mechanism design looks at designing a mechanism to produce the most desirable outcome for the entity running the mechanism.
This problem is well studied for the auction design problem where the optimal mechanism is the one that brings the seller the most profit.
Here, the classical approach is to design such a mechanism given the prior distribution from which the bidders preferences are drawn (See e.g., [12, 4]).
Recently Goldberg et al. [9] introduced the use of worst-case competitive analysis (See e.g., [3]) to analyze the performance of auctions that have no knowledge of the prior distribution.
The goal of such work is to design an auction that achieves a large constant fraction of the profit attainable by an optimal mechanism that knows the prior distribution in advance.

Positive results in this direction are fueled by the observation that in auctions for a number of identical units, much of the distribution from which the bidders are drawn can be deduced on the fly by the auction as it is being run [9, 14, 2].

The performance of an auction in such a worst-case competitive analysis is measured by its competitive ratio, the ratio between a benchmark performance and the auctions performance on the input distribution that maximizes this ratio.
The holy grail of the worstcase competitive analysis of auctions is the auction that achieves the optimal competitive ratio (as small as possible).

Since [9] this search has led to improved understanding of the nature of the optimal auction, the techniques for on-the-fly pricing in these scenarios, and the competitive ratio of the optimal auction [5, 7, 8].
In this paper we continue this line of research by improving in all of these directions.
Furthermore, we give evidence corroborating the conjecture that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in the auctions competitive analysis.
This result further validates the use of competitive analysis in gauging auction performance.
We consider the single item, multi-unit, unit-demand auction problem.
In such an auction there are many units of a single item available for sale to bidders who each desire only one unit.
Each bidder has a valuation representing how much the item is worth to him.
The auction is performed by soliciting a sealed bid from each of the bidders and deciding on the allocation of units to bidders and the prices to be paid by the bidders.
The bidders are assumed to bid so as to maximize their personal utility, the difference between their valuation and the price they pay.

To handle the problem of designing and analyzing auctions where bidders may falsely declare their valuations to get a better deal, we will adopt the solution concept of truthful mechanism design (see, e.g., [9, 15, 13]).
In a truthful auction, revealing ones true valuation as ones bid is an optimal strategy for each bidder regardless of the bids of the other bidders.
In this paper, we will restrict our attention to truthful (a.k.a., incentive compatible or strategyproof) auctions.
A particularly interesting special case of the auction problem is the unlimited supply case.
In this case the number of units for sale is at least the number of bidders in the auction.
This is natural for the sale of digital goods where there is negligible cost for duplicating 175 and distributing the good.
Pay-per-view television and downloadable audio files are examples of such goods.

The competitive framework introduced in [9] and further refined in [5] uses the profit of the optimal omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units as the benchmark for competitive analysis.

The assumption that two or more units are sold is necessary because in the worst case it is impossible to obtain a constant fraction of the profit of the optimal mechanism when it sells only one unit [9].
In this framework for competitive analysis, an auction is said to be β-competitive if it achieves a profit that is within a factor of β ≥ 1 of the benchmark profit on every input.
The optimal auction is the one which is β-competitive with the minimum value of β.

Previous to this work, the best known auction for the unlimited supply case had a competitive ratio of 3.39 [7] and the best lower

For the limited supply case, auctions can achieve substantially better competitive ratios.

When there are only two units for sale, the optimal auction gives a competitive ratio of 2, which matches the lower

When there are three units for sale, the best previously known auction had a competitive ratio of 2.3, compared with a lower

This mechanism is a special case of a general cost-sharing schema due to Moulin and Shenker [11].
The goal of profit extraction is, given bids b, to extract a target value R of profit from some subset of the bidders.
ProfitExtractR: Given bids b, find the largest k such that the highest k bidders can equally share the cost R. Charge each of these bidders R/k.
If no subset of bidders can cover the cost, the mechanism has no winners.
Important properties of this auction are as follows: • ProfitExtractR is truthful. • If R ≤ F(b), ProfitExtractR(b) = R; otherwise it has no winners and no revenue.
We will use this profit extraction mechanism in Section 5 with the following intuition.
Such a profit extractor makes it possible to treat this subset of bidders as a single bid with value F(S).
Note that given a single bid, b, a truthful mechanism might offer it price t and if t ≤ b then the bidder wins and pays t; otherwise the bidder pays nothing (and loses).
Likewise, a mechanism can offer the set of bidders S a target revenue R. If R ≤ F(2) (S), then ProfitExtractR raises R from S; otherwise, the it raises no revenue from S. 3.

One can do better by choosing the auction that is optimally competitive against a specially tailored benchmark.

To see why this might be the case, notice (Table 1) that the fraction of F(2) (b) raised for when there are k = 2 and k = 3 winning bidders in F(2) (b) is substantially smaller than the fraction of F(2) (b) raised when there are more winners.

If we chose a three bidder auction that performed better when F(2) has smaller numbers of winners, our aggregation auction would perform better in the worst case.
One approach is to compete against a different benchmark that puts more weight than F(2) on solutions with a small number of winners.

CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK We have found the optimal auction for the three-unit limitedsupply case, and shown that its structure is essentially independent of the benchmark used in its competitive analysis.
We have then used this auction to derive the best known auction for the unlimited supply case.
Our work leaves many interesting open questions.

We found that the lower
bound
of [8] is matched by an auction for three bidders, 181 even when competing against generalized benchmarks.

The most interesting open question from our work is whether the lower
bound
from Theorem 2 can be matched by an auction for more than three bidders.
We conjecture that it can.
Second, we consider whether our techniques can be extended to find optimal auctions for greater numbers of bidders.

The use of our analytic solution method requires knowledge of a restricted class of auctions which is large enough to contain an optimal auction but small enough that the optimal auction in this class can be found explicitly through analytic methods.
No class of auctions which meets these criteria is known even for the four bidder case.
Also, when the number of bidders is greater than three, it might be the case that the optimal auction is not expressible in terms of elementary functions.
Another interesting set of open questions concerns aggregation auctions.
As we show, the aggregation auction for Υ3 outperforms the aggregation auction for Υ2 and it appears that the aggregation auction for Υ3 is better than Υm for m > 3.
We leave verification of this conjecture for future work.

We also show that Υ3 is not the best three-bidder auction for use in an aggregation auction, but the auction that beats it is able to reduce the competitive ratio of the overall auction only a little bit.
It would be interesting to know whether for any m there is an m-aggregation auction that substantially improves on the competitive ratio of AggΥm .
Finally, we remark that very little is known about the structure of the optimal competitive auction.
In our auction Υ3, the sales price for a given bidder is restricted either to be one of the other bid values or to be higher than all other bid values.
The optimal auction for two bidders, the 1-unit Vickrey auction, also falls within this class of auctions, as its sales prices are restricted to bid values.
We conjecture that an optimal auction for any number of bidders lies within this class.

Our paper provides partial evidence for this conjecture: the lower
bound
of Section 6 on conservative auctions shows that the optimal auction must offer sales prices higher than any bid value if the lower
bound
of Theorem 2 is tight, as is conjectured.
It remains to show that optimal auctions otherwise only offer sales prices at bid values. 8.

Desde Optimal Limited hasta Subastas de Suministro Ilimitado Jason D. Hartline Microsoft Research 1065 La Avenida) Mountain View, CA 94043 hartline@microsoft.com Robert McGrew ∗ Departamento de Ciencias de la Computación Universidad de Stanford Stanford, CA 94305 bmcgrew@stanford.edu RESUMEN Investigamos la clase de subastas de una sola ronda y oferta sellada para un conjunto de artículos idénticos para postores que desean una unidad cada uno. Adoptamos el marco competitivo del peor caso definido por [9, 5] que compara la ganancia de una subasta con la de una venta óptima de precio único de al menos dos artículos. En este artículo, primero derivamos una subasta óptima para tres artículos, respondiendo a una pregunta abierta de [8]. Segundo, demostramos que la forma de esta subasta es independiente del marco competitivo utilizado. Tercero, proponemos un esquema para convertir una subasta de suministro limitado dada en una subasta de suministro ilimitado. Aplicando esta técnica a nuestra subasta óptima de tres artículos, logramos una subasta con una proporción competitiva de 3.25, que mejora la proporción competitiva previamente conocida de 3.39 de [7]. Finalmente, generalizamos un resultado de [8] y ampliamos nuestra comprensión de la naturaleza de la subasta competitiva óptima al mostrar que la subasta competitiva óptima ocasionalmente ofrece precios que son más altos que todos los valores de las ofertas. INTRODUCCIÓN El área de investigación del diseño de mecanismos óptimos se enfoca en diseñar un mecanismo para producir el resultado más deseable para la entidad que lo opera. Este problema está bien estudiado para el problema de diseño de subastas, donde el mecanismo óptimo es aquel que le brinda al vendedor la mayor ganancia. Aquí, el enfoque clásico es diseñar un mecanismo dado la distribución previa de la cual se extraen las preferencias de los postores (Ver, por ejemplo, [12, 4]). Recientemente, Goldberg et al. [9] introdujeron el uso del análisis competitivo del peor caso (ver, por ejemplo, [3]) para analizar el rendimiento de subastas que no tienen conocimiento de la distribución previa. El objetivo de este trabajo es diseñar una subasta que logre una fracción constante grande de la ganancia alcanzable por un mecanismo óptimo que conoce la distribución previa de antemano. Los resultados positivos en esta dirección son impulsados por la observación de que en subastas de un número de unidades idénticas, gran parte de la distribución de la cual se extraen los postores puede ser deducida sobre la marcha por la subasta mientras se lleva a cabo [9, 14, 2]. El rendimiento de una subasta en un análisis competitivo de peor caso se mide por su relación competitiva, la proporción entre un rendimiento de referencia y el rendimiento de la subasta en la distribución de entrada que maximiza esta proporción. El Santo Grial del análisis competitivo del peor caso de subastas es la subasta que logra la proporción competitiva óptima (tan pequeña como sea posible). Desde [9], esta búsqueda ha llevado a una mejor comprensión de la naturaleza de la subasta óptima, las técnicas para la fijación de precios sobre la marcha en estos escenarios y la proporción competitiva de la subasta óptima [5, 7, 8]. En este artículo continuamos esta línea de investigación mejorando en todas estas direcciones. Además, presentamos evidencia que corrobora la conjetura de que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo de las subastas. Este resultado valida aún más el uso del análisis competitivo para medir el rendimiento de una subasta. Consideramos el problema de la subasta de un solo artículo, multiunidad y demanda unitaria. En una subasta de este tipo, hay muchas unidades de un solo artículo disponibles para la venta a postores que desean solo una unidad. Cada postor tiene una valoración que representa cuánto vale el artículo para él. La subasta se realiza solicitando una oferta sellada de cada uno de los postores y decidiendo la asignación de unidades a los postores y los precios a ser pagados por los postores. Se asume que los postores realizan sus ofertas con el fin de maximizar su utilidad personal, la diferencia entre su valoración y el precio que pagan. Para abordar el problema de diseñar y analizar subastas donde los postores pueden declarar falsamente sus valoraciones para obtener un mejor trato, adoptaremos el concepto de diseño de mecanismos veraces (ver, por ejemplo, [9, 15, 13]). En una subasta veraz, revelar la verdadera valoración como oferta es una estrategia óptima para cada postor, independientemente de las ofertas de los demás postores. En este documento, restringiremos nuestra atención a las subastas veraces (también conocidas como compatibles con incentivos o a prueba de estrategias). Un caso especial particularmente interesante del problema de la subasta es el caso de suministro ilimitado. En este caso, el número de unidades en venta es al menos igual al número de postores en la subasta. Esto es natural para la venta de bienes digitales donde hay un costo insignificante para duplicar y distribuir el bien. La televisión de pago por visión y los archivos de audio descargables son ejemplos de tales bienes. El marco competitivo introducido en [9] y posteriormente refinado en [5] utiliza la ganancia del mecanismo de precios único óptimo omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades como referencia para el análisis competitivo. La suposición de que se venden dos o más unidades es necesaria porque en el peor de los casos es imposible obtener una fracción constante de la ganancia del mecanismo óptimo cuando vende solo una unidad [9]. En este marco de análisis competitivo, se dice que una subasta es β-competitiva si logra un beneficio que está dentro de un factor de β ≥ 1 del beneficio de referencia en cada entrada. La subasta óptima es aquella que es β-competitiva con el valor mínimo de β. Antes de este trabajo, la subasta más conocida para el caso de suministro ilimitado tenía una proporción competitiva de 3.39 [7] y el mejor
límite
inferior conocido era de 2.42 [8]. Para el caso de suministro limitado, las subastas pueden lograr ratios competitivos considerablemente mejores. Cuando solo hay dos unidades en venta, la subasta óptima proporciona una proporción competitiva de 2, que coincide con el
límite
inferior para dos unidades. Cuando hay tres unidades en venta, la mejor subasta previamente conocida tuvo una relación competitiva de 2.3, en comparación con un
límite inferior
de 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8]. Los resultados de este documento son los siguientes: • Presentamos la subasta de tres unidades que es óptimamente competitiva frente a las ganancias del mecanismo de precio único omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades. Esta subasta logra una proporción competitiva de 13/6, igualando el
límite
inferior de [8] (Sección 3). • Mostramos que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo. Al hacerlo, proporcionamos una subasta óptima de tres postores para referencias generalizadas (Sección 4). • Presentamos una técnica general para convertir una subasta de oferta limitada en una subasta de oferta ilimitada, donde es posible utilizar la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta limitada para obtener un
límite
en la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta ilimitada.

Hartline Microsoft Research 1065 La Avenida) Mountain View, CA 94043 hartline@microsoft.com Robert McGrew ∗ Computer Science Department Stanford University Stanford, CA 94305 bmcgrew@stanford.edu ABSTRACT We investigate the class of single-round, sealed-bid auctions for a set of identical items to bidders who each desire one unit.
We adopt the worst-case competitive framework defined by [9, 5] that compares the profit of an auction to that of an optimal single-price sale of least two items.
In this paper, we first derive an optimal auction for three items, answering an open question from [8].
Second, we show that the form of this auction is independent of the competitive framework used.
Third, we propose a schema for converting a given limited-supply auction into an unlimited supply auction.

Applying this technique to our optimal auction for three items, we achieve an auction with a competitive ratio of 3.25, which improves upon the previously best-known competitive ratio of 3.39 from [7].

Finally, we generalize a result from [8] and extend our understanding of the nature of the optimal competitive auction by showing that the optimal competitive auction occasionally offers prices that are higher than all bid values.

Categories and Subject Descriptors F.2.2 [Analysis of Algorithms and Problem Complexity]: Nonnumerical Algorithms and Problems; J.4 [Social and Behavioral Sciences]: Economics General Terms Algorithms, Economics, Theory 1.
INTRODUCTION The research area of optimal mechanism design looks at designing a mechanism to produce the most desirable outcome for the entity running the mechanism.
This problem is well studied for the auction design problem where the optimal mechanism is the one that brings the seller the most profit.

Here, the classical approach is to design such a mechanism given the prior distribution from which the bidders
preference
s are drawn (See e.g., [12, 4]).
Recently Goldberg et al. [9] introduced the use of worst-case competitive analysis (See e.g., [3]) to analyze the performance of auctions that have no knowledge of the prior distribution.
The goal of such work is to design an auction that achieves a large constant fraction of the profit attainable by an optimal mechanism that knows the prior distribution in advance.

Positive results in this direction are fueled by the observation that in auctions for a number of identical units, much of the distribution from which the bidders are drawn can be deduced on the fly by the auction as it is being run [9, 14, 2].

The performance of an auction in such a worst-case competitive analysis is measured by its competitive ratio, the ratio between a benchmark performance and the auctions performance on the input distribution that maximizes this ratio.
The holy grail of the worstcase competitive analysis of auctions is the auction that achieves the optimal competitive ratio (as small as possible).

Since [9] this search has led to improved understanding of the nature of the optimal auction, the techniques for on-the-fly pricing in these scenarios, and the competitive ratio of the optimal auction [5, 7, 8].
In this paper we continue this line of research by improving in all of these directions.
Furthermore, we give evidence corroborating the conjecture that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in the auctions competitive analysis.
This result further validates the use of competitive analysis in gauging auction performance.
We consider the single item, multi-unit, unit-demand auction problem.
In such an auction there are many units of a single item available for sale to bidders who each desire only one unit.
Each bidder has a valuation representing how much the item is worth to him.
The auction is performed by soliciting a sealed bid from each of the bidders and deciding on the allocation of units to bidders and the prices to be paid by the bidders.
The bidders are assumed to bid so as to maximize their personal utility, the difference between their valuation and the price they pay.

To handle the problem of designing and analyzing auctions where bidders may falsely declare their valuations to get a better deal, we will adopt the solution concept of truthful mechanism design (see, e.g., [9, 15, 13]).
In a truthful auction, revealing ones true valuation as ones bid is an optimal strategy for each bidder regardless of the bids of the other bidders.
In this paper, we will restrict our attention to truthful (a.k.a., incentive compatible or strategyproof) auctions.
A particularly interesting special case of the auction problem is the unlimited supply case.
In this case the number of units for sale is at least the number of bidders in the auction.
This is natural for the sale of digital goods where there is negligible cost for duplicating 175 and distributing the good.
Pay-per-view television and downloadable audio files are examples of such goods.

The competitive framework introduced in [9] and further refined in [5] uses the profit of the optimal omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units as the benchmark for competitive analysis.

The assumption that two or more units are sold is necessary because in the worst case it is impossible to obtain a constant fraction of the profit of the optimal mechanism when it sells only one unit [9].
In this framework for competitive analysis, an auction is said to be β-competitive if it achieves a profit that is within a factor of β ≥ 1 of the benchmark profit on every input.
The optimal auction is the one which is β-competitive with the minimum value of β.
Previous to this work, the best known auction for the unlimited supply case had a competitive ratio of 3.39 [7] and the best lower bound known was 2.42 [8].
For the limited supply case, auctions can achieve substantially better competitive ratios.
When there are only two units for sale, the optimal auction gives a competitive ratio of 2, which matches the lower bound for two units.
When there are three units for sale, the best previously known auction had a competitive ratio of 2.3, compared with a lower bound of 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8].

The results of this paper are as follows: • We give the auction for three units that is optimally competitive against the profit of the omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units.

This auction achieves a competitive ratio of 13/6, matching the lower bound from [8] (Section 3). • We show that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in competitive analysis.

In doing so, we give an optimal three bidder auction for generalized benchmarks (Section 4). • We give a general technique for converting a limited supply auction into an unlimited supply auction where it is possible to use the competitive ratio of the limited supply auction to obtain a bound on the competitive ratio of the unlimited supply auction.

We refer to auctions derived from this framework as aggregation auctions (Section 5). • We improve on the best known competitive ratio by proving that the aggregation auction constructed from our optimal three-unit auction is 3.25-competitive (Section 5.1). • Assuming that the conjecture that the optimal -unit auction has a competitive ratio that matches the lower bound proved in [8], we show that this optimal auction for ≥ 3 on some inputs will occasionally offer prices that are higher than any bid in that input (Section 6).
For the three-unit case where we have shown that the lower bound of [8] is tight, this observation led to our construction of the optimal three-unit auction. 2.

This mechanism is a special case of a general cost-sharing schema due to Moulin and Shenker [11].
The goal of profit extraction is, given bids b, to extract a target value R of profit from some subset of the bidders.
ProfitExtractR: Given bids b, find the largest k such that the highest k bidders can equally share the cost R. Charge each of these bidders R/k.
If no subset of bidders can cover the cost, the mechanism has no winners.
Important properties of this auction are as follows: • ProfitExtractR is truthful. • If R ≤ F(b), ProfitExtractR(b) = R; otherwise it has no winners and no revenue.
We will use this profit extraction mechanism in Section 5 with the following intuition.
Such a profit extractor makes it possible to treat this subset of bidders as a single bid with value F(S).
Note that given a single bid, b, a truthful mechanism might offer it price t and if t ≤ b then the bidder wins and pays t; otherwise the bidder pays nothing (and loses).
Likewise, a mechanism can offer the set of bidders S a target revenue R. If R ≤ F(2) (S), then ProfitExtractR raises R from S; otherwise, the it raises no revenue from S. 3.

CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK We have found the optimal auction for the three-unit limitedsupply case, and shown that its structure is essentially independent of the benchmark used in its competitive analysis.
We have then used this auction to derive the best known auction for the unlimited supply case.
Our work leaves many interesting open questions.
We found that the lower bound of [8] is matched by an auction for three bidders, 181 even when competing against generalized benchmarks.
The most interesting open question from our work is whether the lower bound from Theorem 2 can be matched by an auction for more than three bidders.
We conjecture that it can.
Second, we consider whether our techniques can be extended to find optimal auctions for greater numbers of bidders.

The use of our analytic solution method requires knowledge of a restricted class of auctions which is large enough to contain an optimal auction but small enough that the optimal auction in this class can be found explicitly through analytic methods.
No class of auctions which meets these criteria is known even for the four bidder case.
Also, when the number of bidders is greater than three, it might be the case that the optimal auction is not expressible in terms of elementary functions.
Another interesting set of open questions concerns aggregation auctions.
As we show, the aggregation auction for Υ3 outperforms the aggregation auction for Υ2 and it appears that the aggregation auction for Υ3 is better than Υm for m > 3.
We leave verification of this conjecture for future work.

We also show that Υ3 is not the best three-bidder auction for use in an aggregation auction, but the auction that beats it is able to reduce the competitive ratio of the overall auction only a little bit.
It would be interesting to know whether for any m there is an m-aggregation auction that substantially improves on the competitive ratio of AggΥm .
Finally, we remark that very little is known about the structure of the optimal competitive auction.
In our auction Υ3, the sales price for a given bidder is restricted either to be one of the other bid values or to be higher than all other bid values.
The optimal auction for two bidders, the 1-unit Vickrey auction, also falls within this class of auctions, as its sales prices are restricted to bid values.
We conjecture that an optimal auction for any number of bidders lies within this class.

Our paper provides partial evidence for this conjecture: the lower bound of Section 6 on conservative auctions shows that the optimal auction must offer sales prices higher than any bid value if the lower bound of Theorem 2 is tight, as is conjectured.
It remains to show that optimal auctions otherwise only offer sales prices at bid values. 8.

Hartline Microsoft Research 1065 La Avenida) Mountain View, CA 94043 hartline@microsoft.com Robert McGrew ∗ Departamento de Ciencias de la Computación Universidad de Stanford Stanford, CA 94305 bmcgrew@stanford.edu RESUMEN Investigamos la clase de subastas de una sola ronda y oferta sellada para un conjunto de artículos idénticos para postores que desean una unidad cada uno. Adoptamos el marco competitivo del peor caso definido por [9, 5] que compara la ganancia de una subasta con la de una venta óptima de precio único de al menos dos artículos. En este artículo, primero derivamos una subasta óptima para tres artículos, respondiendo a una pregunta abierta de [8]. Segundo, demostramos que la forma de esta subasta es independiente del marco competitivo utilizado. Tercero, proponemos un esquema para convertir una subasta de suministro limitado dada en una subasta de suministro ilimitado. Aplicando esta técnica a nuestra subasta óptima de tres artículos, logramos una subasta con una proporción competitiva de 3.25, que mejora la proporción competitiva previamente conocida de 3.39 de [7]. Finalmente, generalizamos un resultado de [8] y ampliamos nuestra comprensión de la naturaleza de la subasta competitiva óptima al mostrar que la subasta competitiva óptima ocasionalmente ofrece precios que son más altos que todos los valores de las ofertas. INTRODUCCIÓN El área de investigación del diseño de mecanismos óptimos se enfoca en diseñar un mecanismo para producir el resultado más deseable para la entidad que lo opera. Este problema está bien estudiado para el problema de diseño de subastas, donde el mecanismo óptimo es aquel que le brinda al vendedor la mayor ganancia. Aquí, el enfoque clásico es diseñar un mecanismo dado la distribución previa de la cual se extraen las
preferencias
de los postores (Ver, por ejemplo, [12, 4]). Recientemente, Goldberg et al. [9] introdujeron el uso del análisis competitivo del peor caso (ver, por ejemplo, [3]) para analizar el rendimiento de subastas que no tienen conocimiento de la distribución previa. El objetivo de este trabajo es diseñar una subasta que logre una fracción constante grande de la ganancia alcanzable por un mecanismo óptimo que conoce la distribución previa de antemano. Los resultados positivos en esta dirección son impulsados por la observación de que en subastas de un número de unidades idénticas, gran parte de la distribución de la cual se extraen los postores puede ser deducida sobre la marcha por la subasta mientras se lleva a cabo [9, 14, 2]. El rendimiento de una subasta en un análisis competitivo de peor caso se mide por su relación competitiva, la proporción entre un rendimiento de referencia y el rendimiento de la subasta en la distribución de entrada que maximiza esta proporción. El Santo Grial del análisis competitivo del peor caso de subastas es la subasta que logra la proporción competitiva óptima (tan pequeña como sea posible). Desde [9], esta búsqueda ha llevado a una mejor comprensión de la naturaleza de la subasta óptima, las técnicas para la fijación de precios sobre la marcha en estos escenarios y la proporción competitiva de la subasta óptima [5, 7, 8]. En este artículo continuamos esta línea de investigación mejorando en todas estas direcciones. Además, presentamos evidencia que corrobora la conjetura de que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo de las subastas. Este resultado valida aún más el uso del análisis competitivo para medir el rendimiento de una subasta. Consideramos el problema de la subasta de un solo artículo, multiunidad y demanda unitaria. En una subasta de este tipo, hay muchas unidades de un solo artículo disponibles para la venta a postores que desean solo una unidad. Cada postor tiene una valoración que representa cuánto vale el artículo para él. La subasta se realiza solicitando una oferta sellada de cada uno de los postores y decidiendo la asignación de unidades a los postores y los precios a ser pagados por los postores. Se asume que los postores realizan sus ofertas con el fin de maximizar su utilidad personal, la diferencia entre su valoración y el precio que pagan. Para abordar el problema de diseñar y analizar subastas donde los postores pueden declarar falsamente sus valoraciones para obtener un mejor trato, adoptaremos el concepto de diseño de mecanismos veraces (ver, por ejemplo, [9, 15, 13]). En una subasta veraz, revelar la verdadera valoración como oferta es una estrategia óptima para cada postor, independientemente de las ofertas de los demás postores. En este documento, restringiremos nuestra atención a las subastas veraces (también conocidas como compatibles con incentivos o a prueba de estrategias). Un caso especial particularmente interesante del problema de la subasta es el caso de suministro ilimitado. En este caso, el número de unidades en venta es al menos igual al número de postores en la subasta. Esto es natural para la venta de bienes digitales donde hay un costo insignificante para duplicar y distribuir el bien. La televisión de pago por visión y los archivos de audio descargables son ejemplos de tales bienes. El marco competitivo introducido en [9] y posteriormente refinado en [5] utiliza la ganancia del mecanismo de precios único óptimo omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades como referencia para el análisis competitivo. La suposición de que se venden dos o más unidades es necesaria porque en el peor de los casos es imposible obtener una fracción constante de la ganancia del mecanismo óptimo cuando vende solo una unidad [9]. En este marco de análisis competitivo, se dice que una subasta es β-competitiva si logra un beneficio que está dentro de un factor de β ≥ 1 del beneficio de referencia en cada entrada. La subasta óptima es aquella que es β-competitiva con el valor mínimo de β. Antes de este trabajo, la subasta más conocida para el caso de suministro ilimitado tenía una proporción competitiva de 3.39 [7] y el mejor límite inferior conocido era de 2.42 [8]. Para el caso de suministro limitado, las subastas pueden lograr ratios competitivos considerablemente mejores. Cuando solo hay dos unidades en venta, la subasta óptima proporciona una proporción competitiva de 2, que coincide con el límite inferior para dos unidades. Cuando hay tres unidades en venta, la mejor subasta previamente conocida tuvo una relación competitiva de 2.3, en comparación con un límite inferior de 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8]. Los resultados de este documento son los siguientes: • Presentamos la subasta de tres unidades que es óptimamente competitiva frente a las ganancias del mecanismo de precio único omnisciente que vende al menos dos unidades. Esta subasta logra una proporción competitiva de 13/6, igualando el límite inferior de [8] (Sección 3). • Mostramos que la forma de la subasta óptima es independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en el análisis competitivo. Al hacerlo, proporcionamos una subasta óptima de tres postores para referencias generalizadas (Sección 4). • Presentamos una técnica general para convertir una subasta de oferta limitada en una subasta de oferta ilimitada, donde es posible utilizar la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta limitada para obtener un límite en la proporción competitiva de la subasta de oferta ilimitada. Nos referimos a las subastas derivadas de este marco como subastas de agregación (Sección 5). • Mejoramos la mejor proporción competitiva conocida al demostrar que la subasta de agregación construida a partir de nuestra subasta óptima de tres unidades es 3.25-competitiva (Sección 5.1). • Suponiendo que la conjetura de que la subasta óptima de -unidades tiene una proporción competitiva que coincide con el límite inferior demostrado en [8], mostramos que esta subasta óptima para ≥ 3 en algunos insumos ocasionalmente ofrecerá precios más altos que cualquier oferta en ese insumo (Sección 6). Para el caso de tres unidades en el que hemos demostrado que el límite inferior de [8] es ajustado, esta observación condujo a nuestra construcción de la subasta óptima de tres unidades. 2. Este mecanismo es un caso especial de un esquema general de reparto de costos debido a Moulin y Shenker [11]. El objetivo de la extracción de beneficios es, dadas las ofertas b, extraer un valor objetivo R de beneficio de algún subconjunto de los oferentes. ProfitExtractR: Dados los ofertas b, encuentra el valor más grande de k tal que los k postores más altos puedan compartir igualmente el costo R. Cobra a cada uno de estos postores R/k. Si ningún subconjunto de postores puede cubrir el costo, el mecanismo no tiene ganadores. Las propiedades importantes de esta subasta son las siguientes: • ProfitExtractR es veraz. • Si R ≤ F(b), ProfitExtractR(b) = R; de lo contrario, no tiene ganadores ni ingresos. Utilizaremos este mecanismo de extracción de beneficios en la Sección 5 con la siguiente intuición. Un extractor de ganancias de este tipo permite tratar a este subconjunto de postores como una única oferta con valor F(S). Ten en cuenta que dado un único ofrecimiento, b, un mecanismo veraz podría ofrecer un precio t y si t ≤ b entonces el postor gana y paga t; de lo contrario, el postor no paga nada (y pierde). Del mismo modo, un mecanismo puede ofrecer al conjunto de postores S un ingreso objetivo R. CONCLUSIONES Y TRABAJO FUTURO Hemos encontrado la subasta óptima para el caso de suministro limitado de tres unidades, y hemos demostrado que su estructura es esencialmente independiente del punto de referencia utilizado en su análisis competitivo. Hemos utilizado esta subasta para derivar la subasta mejor conocida para el caso de suministro ilimitado. Nuestro trabajo deja muchas preguntas abiertas interesantes. Encontramos que el límite inferior de [8] es igualado por una subasta para tres postores, 181 incluso al competir contra referencias generales. La pregunta abierta más interesante de nuestro trabajo es si el límite inferior del Teorema 2 puede ser igualado por una subasta para más de tres postores. Conjeturamos que puede ser así. Segundo, consideramos si nuestras técnicas pueden ser ampliadas para encontrar subastas óptimas para un mayor número de postores. El uso de nuestro método de solución analítica requiere conocimiento de una clase restringida de subastas que sea lo suficientemente grande como para contener una subasta óptima, pero lo suficientemente pequeña como para que la subasta óptima de esta clase pueda encontrarse explícitamente a través de métodos analíticos. No se conoce ninguna clase de subastas que cumpla con estos criterios, ni siquiera para el caso de cuatro postores. Además, cuando el número de postores es mayor a tres, podría darse el caso de que la subasta óptima no sea expresable en términos de funciones elementales. Otro conjunto interesante de preguntas abiertas se refiere a las subastas de agregación. Como mostramos, la subasta de agregación para Υ3 supera a la subasta de agregación para Υ2 y parece que la subasta de agregación para Υ3 es mejor que Υm para m > 3. Dejamos la verificación de esta conjetura para trabajos futuros. También demostramos que Υ3 no es la mejor subasta de tres postores para utilizar en una subasta de agregación, pero la subasta que la supera logra reducir solo un poco la proporción competitiva de la subasta en general. Sería interesante saber si para cualquier m existe una subasta de m-agregación que mejore sustancialmente la proporción competitiva de AggΥm. Finalmente, cabe destacar que se sabe muy poco sobre la estructura de la subasta competitiva óptima. En nuestra subasta Υ3, el precio de venta para un postor dado está restringido a ser uno de los otros valores de oferta o ser más alto que todos los demás valores de oferta. La subasta óptima para dos postores, la subasta de Vickrey de 1 unidad, también se encuentra dentro de esta clase de subastas, ya que sus precios de venta están restringidos a los valores de las ofertas. Conjeturamos que una subasta óptima para cualquier número de postores se encuentra dentro de esta clase. Nuestro artículo proporciona evidencia parcial para esta conjetura: el límite inferior de la Sección 6 sobre subastas conservadoras muestra que la subasta óptima debe ofrecer precios de venta más altos que cualquier valor de oferta si el límite inferior del Teorema 2 es ajustado, como se conjetura. Queda por demostrar que las subastas óptimas solo ofrecen precios de venta en los valores de oferta. Hartline Microsoft Research 1065 La Avenida) Mountain View, CA 94043 hartline@microsoft.com Robert McGrew ∗ Computer Science Department Stanford University Stanford, CA 94305 bmcgrew@stanford.edu ABSTRACT We investigate the class of single-round, sealed-bid auctions for a set of identical items to bidders who each desire one unit.
We adopt the worst-case competitive framework defined by [9, 5] that compares the profit of an auction to that of an optimal single-price sale of least two items.
In this paper, we first derive an optimal auction for three items, answering an open question from [8].
Second, we show that the form of this auction is independent of the competitive framework used.
Third, we propose a schema for converting a given limited-supply auction into an unlimited supply auction.

Applying this technique to our optimal auction for three items, we achieve an auction with a competitive ratio of 3.25, which improves upon the previously best-known competitive ratio of 3.39 from [7].

Finally, we generalize a result from [8] and extend our understanding of the nature of the optimal competitive auction by showing that the optimal competitive auction occasionally offers prices that are higher than all bid values.

INTRODUCTION The research area of optimal mechanism design looks at designing a mechanism to produce the most desirable outcome for the entity running the mechanism.
This problem is well studied for the auction design problem where the optimal mechanism is the one that brings the seller the most profit.

Here, the classical approach is to design such a mechanism given the prior
distribution
from which the bidders preferences are drawn (See e.g., [12, 4]).

Recently Goldberg et al. [9] introduced the use of worst-case competitive analysis (See e.g., [3]) to analyze the performance of auctions that have no knowledge of the prior
distribution
.

The goal of such work is to design an auction that achieves a large constant fraction of the profit attainable by an optimal mechanism that knows the prior
distribution
in advance.

Positive results in this direction are fueled by the observation that in auctions for a number of identical units, much of the
distribution
from which the bidders are drawn can be deduced on the fly by the auction as it is being run [9, 14, 2].

The performance of an auction in such a worst-case competitive analysis is measured by its competitive ratio, the ratio between a benchmark performance and the auctions performance on the input
distribution
that maximizes this ratio.
The holy grail of the worstcase competitive analysis of auctions is the auction that achieves the optimal competitive ratio (as small as possible).

Since [9] this search has led to improved understanding of the nature of the optimal auction, the techniques for on-the-fly pricing in these scenarios, and the competitive ratio of the optimal auction [5, 7, 8].
In this paper we continue this line of research by improving in all of these directions.
Furthermore, we give evidence corroborating the conjecture that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in the auctions competitive analysis.
This result further validates the use of competitive analysis in gauging auction performance.
We consider the single item, multi-unit, unit-demand auction problem.
In such an auction there are many units of a single item available for sale to bidders who each desire only one unit.
Each bidder has a valuation representing how much the item is worth to him.
The auction is performed by soliciting a sealed bid from each of the bidders and deciding on the allocation of units to bidders and the prices to be paid by the bidders.
The bidders are assumed to bid so as to maximize their personal utility, the difference between their valuation and the price they pay.

To handle the problem of designing and analyzing auctions where bidders may falsely declare their valuations to get a better deal, we will adopt the solution concept of truthful mechanism design (see, e.g., [9, 15, 13]).
In a truthful auction, revealing ones true valuation as ones bid is an optimal strategy for each bidder regardless of the bids of the other bidders.
In this paper, we will restrict our attention to truthful (a.k.a., incentive compatible or strategyproof) auctions.
A particularly interesting special case of the auction problem is the unlimited supply case.
In this case the number of units for sale is at least the number of bidders in the auction.
This is natural for the sale of digital goods where there is negligible cost for duplicating 175 and distributing the good.
Pay-per-view television and downloadable audio files are examples of such goods.

The competitive framework introduced in [9] and further refined in [5] uses the profit of the optimal omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units as the benchmark for competitive analysis.

The assumption that two or more units are sold is necessary because in the worst case it is impossible to obtain a constant fraction of the profit of the optimal mechanism when it sells only one unit [9].
In this framework for competitive analysis, an auction is said to be β-competitive if it achieves a profit that is within a factor of β ≥ 1 of the benchmark profit on every input.
The optimal auction is the one which is β-competitive with the minimum value of β.
Previous to this work, the best known auction for the unlimited supply case had a competitive ratio of 3.39 [7] and the best lower bound known was 2.42 [8].
For the limited supply case, auctions can achieve substantially better competitive ratios.
When there are only two units for sale, the optimal auction gives a competitive ratio of 2, which matches the lower bound for two units.
When there are three units for sale, the best previously known auction had a competitive ratio of 2.3, compared with a lower bound of 13/6 ≈ 2.17 [8].

The results of this paper are as follows: • We give the auction for three units that is optimally competitive against the profit of the omniscient single priced mechanism that sells at least two units.

This auction achieves a competitive ratio of 13/6, matching the lower bound from [8] (Section 3). • We show that the form of the optimal auction is independent of the benchmark used in competitive analysis.

In doing so, we give an optimal three bidder auction for generalized benchmarks (Section 4). • We give a general technique for converting a limited supply auction into an unlimited supply auction where it is possible to use the competitive ratio of the limited supply auction to obtain a bound on the competitive ratio of the unlimited supply auction.

We refer to auctions derived from this framework as aggregation auctions (Section 5). • We improve on the best known competitive ratio by proving that the aggregation auction constructed from our optimal three-unit auction is 3.25-competitive (Section 5.1). • Assuming that the conjecture that the optimal -unit auction has a competitive ratio that matches the lower bound proved in [8], we show that this optimal auction for ≥ 3 on some inputs will occasionally offer prices that are higher than any bid in that input (Section 6).
For the three-unit case where we have shown that the lower bound of [8] is tight, this observation led to our construction of the optimal three-unit auction. 2.

It is conjectured that this lower bound is tight for any number of bidders and the optimal auction, Υn, matches it. 1 The 1-unit Vickrey auction sells to the highest bidder at the second highest bid value. 2.5 Profit Extraction In this section we review the truthful profit extraction mechanism ProfitExtractR.
This mechanism is a special case of a general cost-sharing schema due to Moulin and Shenker [11].
The goal of profit extraction is, given bids b, to extract a target value R of profit from some subset of the bidders.
ProfitExtractR: Given bids b, find the largest k such that the highest k bidders can equally share the cost R. Charge each of these bidders R/k.
If no subset of bidders can cover the cost, the mechanism has no winners.
Important properties of this auction are as follows: • ProfitExtractR is truthful. • If R ≤ F(b), ProfitExtractR(b) = R; otherwise it has no winners and no revenue.
We will use this profit extraction mechanism in Section 5 with the following intuition.
Such a profit extractor makes it possible to treat this subset of bidders as a single bid with value F(S).
Note that given a single bid, b, a truthful mechanism might offer it price t and if t ≤ b then the bidder wins and pays t; otherwise the bidder pays nothing (and loses).
Likewise, a mechanism can offer the set of bidders S a target revenue R. If R ≤ F(2) (S), then ProfitExtractR raises R from S; otherwise, the it raises no revenue from S. 3.

CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK We have found the optimal auction for the three-unit limitedsupply case, and shown that its structure is essentially independent of the benchmark used in its competitive analysis.
We have then used this auction to derive the best known auction for the unlimited supply case.
Our work leaves many interesting open questions.
We found that the lower bound of [8] is matched by an auction for three bidders, 181 even when competing against generalized benchmarks.
The most interesting open question from our work is whether the lower bound from Theorem 2 can be matched by an auction for more than three bidders.
We conjecture that it can.
Second, we consider whether our techniques can be extended to find optimal auctions for greater numbers of bidders.

The use of our analytic solution method requires knowledge of a restricted class of auctions which is large enough to contain an optimal auction but small enough that the optimal auction in this class can be found explicitly through analytic methods.
No class of auctions which meets these criteria is known even for the four bidder case.
Also, when the number of bidders is greater than three, it might be the case that the optimal auction is not expressible in terms of elementary functions.
Another interesting set of open questions concerns aggregation auctions.
As we show, the aggregation auction for Υ3 outperforms the aggregation auction for Υ2 and it appears that the aggregation auction for Υ3 is better than Υm for m > 3.
We leave verification of this conjecture for future work.

We also show that Υ3 is not the best three-bidder auction for use in an aggregation auction, but the auction that beats it is able to reduce the competitive ratio of the overall auction only a little bit.
It would be interesting to know whether for any m there is an m-aggregation auction that substantially improves on the competitive ratio of AggΥm .
Finally, we remark that very little is known about the structure of the optimal competitive auction.
In our auction Υ3, the sales price for a given bidder is restricted either to be one of the other bid values or to be higher than all other bid values.
The optimal auction for two bidders, the 1-unit Vickrey auction, also falls within this class of auctions, as its sales prices are restricted to bid values.
We conjecture that an optimal auction for any number of bidders lies within this class.

Our paper provides partial evidence for this conjecture: the lower bound of Section 6 on conservative auctions shows that the optimal auction must offer sales prices higher than any bid value if the lower bound of Theorem 2 is tight, as is conjectured.
It remains to show that optimal auctions otherwise only offer sales prices at bid values. 8.

Here, the classical approach is to design such a mechanism given the prior
distribution
from which the bidders preferences are drawn (See e.g., [12, 4]).

Recently Goldberg et al. [9] introduced the use of worst-case competitive analysis (See e.g., [3]) to analyze the performance of auctions that have no knowledge of the prior
distribution
.

The goal of such work is to design an auction that achieves a large constant fraction of the profit attainable by an optimal mechanism that knows the prior
distribution
in advance.

Positive results in this direction are fueled by the observation that in auctions for a number of identical units, much of the
distribution
from which the bidders are drawn can be deduced on the fly by the auction as it is being run [9, 14, 2].

The performance of an auction in such a worst-case competitive analysis is measured by its competitive ratio, the ratio between a benchmark performance and the auctions performance on the input
distribution
that maximizes this ratio.
